Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Cell Signaling Hypergraphs: Algorithms and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proteins in the living cell interact with each other in complex ways. Graphs have emerged as a natural way to represent these interactions. In a conventional graph representation, a node represents a protein and an edge represents an interaction between two proteins. Although such graphs have been in widespread use for many years, they do not accurately capture important features of protein interactions, such as proteins that operate in groups called complexes, reactions involving such complexes that may have more than two reactants and products, as well as the influence of other proteins whose presence can regulate reactions. This project will develop a new representation called signaling hypergraphs that naturally describes the relationships between multiple groups of proteins as complexes, reactants, products, and regulators. Furthermore, the project will develop novel algorithms for fundamental computational challenges in the analysis of signaling hypergraphs, and apply this new representation and these algorithms to widely-used databases of cellular reactions.

The project will actively involve undergraduate students in research by recruiting them through the Virginia Tech Initiative to Maximize Student Diversity, and the Virginia Tech Undergraduate Research in Computer Science program. Students will engage in multiple semesters of research with the goal of ultimately leading their own individual projects, and obtaining co-authorship in publications. In this way the project will expose students to how computational thinking plays a major role in modern molecular biology, thereby meeting an important goal of STEM education.

This project focuses on developing algorithms for the analysis of cell signaling hypergraphs. Aim 1 focuses on methods for generating products efficiently by finding short paths through signaling hypergraphs, while accounting for feedback loops and reaction regulators. Aim 2 develops algorithms for discovering missing proteins, complexes, and reactions in a signaling pathway. Finally, Aim 3 will release open-source software implementing the algorithms for signaling hypergraphs developed in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed computational methods for both: (1) inferring reaction pathways in cell signaling networks, and (2) predicting protein secondary structure.

The first problem of inferring reaction pathways can naturally be modeled as finding a so-called shortest hyperpath from a designated source vertex to a designated sink vertex in a directed hypergraph. The reactions in the signaling network are modeled as so-called hyperedges in a hypergraph, where a hyperedge for a reaction is directed from the set of input reactants to the set of ouput reactants. The initial receptors of the pathway are modeled by a source vertex, and the final targets of the pathway are modeled by a sink vertex. A shortest hyperpath from the source to the sink then represents the most economical way of producing the targets starting from the receptors by a series of reactions within the network. While this shortest hyperpath problem is in general computationally intractable in the worst-case, the project developed practical algorithms that for the first time can compute optimal hyperpaths on real-world biological networks involving thousands of reactions.

The second problem of predicting protein secondary structure can be stated as, given the amino acid sequence specifying a protein molecule, to predict the structural state of the amino acids when the protein folds into a three-dimensional structure within a cell, where the states belong to either a coarser three-state model (consisting of alpha-helix, beta-strand, or coil) or a more refined eight-state model. Predicting these secondary structure states is a challenging computational problem that is a precursor to many common tasks in bioinformatics, including predicting the full three-dimensional folded structure of the protein, as well as predicting properties of the protein in the cell. The project advanced the state of the art by developing the most accurate secondary structure prediction tool currently available, which was released as open source software made freely available for research use.

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2021
Modified by: John D Kececioglu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project developed computational methods for both: (1) inferring reaction pathways in cell signaling networks, and (2) predicting protein secondary structure. The first problem of inferring reaction pathways can naturally be modeled as finding a so-called shortest hyperpath from a designated source vertex to a designated sink vertex in a directed hypergraph. The reactions in the signaling network are modeled as so-called hyperedges in a hypergraph, where a hyperedge for a reaction is directed from the set of input reactants to the set of ouput reactants. The initial receptors of the pathway are modeled by a source vertex, and the final targets of the pathway are modeled by a sink vertex. A shortest hyperpath from the source to the sink then represents the most economical way of producing the targets starting from the receptors by a series of reactions within the network. While this shortest hyperpath problem is in general computationally intractable in the worst-case, the project developed practical algorithms that for the first time can compute optimal hyperpaths on real-world biological networks involving thousands of reactions. The second problem of predicting protein secondary structure can be stated as, given the amino acid sequence specifying a protein molecule, to predict the structural state of the amino acids when the protein folds into a three-dimensional structure within a cell, where the states belong to either a coarser three-state model (consisting of alpha-helix, beta-strand, or coil) or a more refined eight-state model. Predicting these secondary structure states is a challenging computational problem that is a precursor to many common tasks in bioinformatics, including predicting the full three-dimensional folded structure of the protein, as well as predicting properties of the protein in the cell. The project advanced the state of the art by developing the most accurate secondary structure prediction tool currently available, which was released as open source software made freely available for research use.
